Emma Raducanu is not only a world-class tennis player at the age of just 18, she's also modest and well-spoken. She's a real asset to this country. And if she can stay injury-free, this is just the start! #USOpen
@SpeedyDragon46 Yep, he handled it well!
@squireyorke Indeed.

Prime Video presenter (who I don't recognise) to Tim Henman: "Tim, how does this compare to winning a title yourself?"

Massive congratulations to Emma Raducanu! What a wonderful Great British success story this is. These are great scenes at Flushing Meadows. To think that this is just the start of the story for her! If she can stay free from injury, the years ahead should be tremendous! #USOpen

The sheer number of survivors, first responders and local residents/workers who have either died or suffered significant health problems from the toxic dust they inhaled on 9/11 and in the period that followed is enormous. They are 9/11 victims too. #911Anniversary

On the 20th anniversary of the 9/11 attacks, we remember the 2,974 people lost their lives that day. However, let us also remember that the death toll continues to rise. 4,343 survivors and first responders have died in the years since. Let us remember them all. #911Anniversary

What a terrific fight that was! Congratulations to Sam Eggington - that was wonderful to watch. I hope we'll be seeing a lot more of Bilel Jkitou in the months and years ahead. He deserves another crack at the big time! #boxing

@Sales_Rainmaker @landlord_secret @DominicFrisby @lordrix @JeremyNoad @MorrisJFM @NewTimeMedia @bushontheradio @landlordwhisprr @MarcusDimbleby @The_Inquisitor @TabHerts @grahambunting @RobinLansman @donutzmonster @bobapollo @acting4sales @SalesHunterPro @Gerald_Ashley Have a good weekend, all!

This is absolutely extraordinary stuff from Emma Raducanu. This tournament is her US Open debut, but she's playing with the confidence and demeanour of a much more experienced, world class player. It's certainly worth staying up late for! #USOpen
RT @Nick_Metcalfe: Quite simply one of the great voices of sport. The peerless Al Michaels. #NFL https://t.co/aw4o2CimgA

@DavidShield23 A Sky Sports subscription in a pub is considerably higher in cost than a domestic subscription. Over the last decade, many pubs have found the rates they're charged increasingly unaffordable. As for DAZN, I don't know what they charge pubs.

In terms of the scope of coverage of the US Open, it's now way ahead of the days when the BBC provided limited coverage. Amazon Prime is a decent platform for entertainment, and increasingly, live sport. But people who aren't tech-savvy often struggle to find it. #USOpen

We have a major British success story to enjoy with Emma Raducanu, and yet it feels as though it's somewhat 'hidden' from view because the UK TV rights are with Amazon Prime. A lot of people who use Prime for shopping etc probably don't know they can watch it. #USOpen

Good luck to Emma Raducanu in her semi-final later tonight. Her rise over the course of the last few months has been extraordinary. I won't call it a 'meteoric' rise, because, as the late Keith Waterhouse pointed out in 'Waterhouse on Newspaper Style', meteors FALL. #USOpen
@glennerboy A war crimes trial would be better-fitting.
@glennerboy Yes, he is treated with a deference and a respectability he does not deserve.

Anthony Blair has a nerve. His lies and deceit have led to the deaths of British and allied service personnel, not to mention countless innocent Afghans and Iraqis. We do well not to treat him as some sort of elder statesman and we shouldn't give him the dignitaries of the role. https://t.co/04he3EGNmk

@RWTaylors "A little research" very often means people looking up cranky conspiracy theorists online. We live in an age where if you decide you believe any conspiracy, you can find an online community to back it up.

I prefer to listen to leading universities and scientists.
@Exsnookerpro @RWTaylors You can indeed, but the vaccine massively reduces the risk of both: https://t.co/Ng8uK49CNP
@RWTaylors The vaccine massively cuts the risk of transmission: https://t.co/Ng8uK49CNP
RT @colinbrazierGBN: The more I read this NHS blog, the more it enrages me. How can any white NHS employee read it without feeling in a Kaf‚Ä¶
RT @NJ_Timothy: When thirteen million of us are on NHS waiting lists, they‚Äôll at least give us something to read. https://t.co/YRw5c6fxQG

@RWTaylors Who? The care home residents? Having the jab will give them a substantial degree of protection. But having the jab also prevents us from spreading Covid to others. And therefore the staff they come into contact with should've had their jabs.

@RWTaylors If you're coming into contact with elderly people in a care home, either as a doctor, nurse, hairdresser or anything else, I expect you to have had your jabs to protect the elderly & vulnerable people you come into contact with.

If you don't like it, find alternative employment.

There are numerous jobs where you're required to have various inoculations as a condition of you taking the job - serving in the armed forces, working in hospitals and care homes, and lots more.

Now, the same applies to the Covid jab. It is NOT an attack on civil liberties.

Nobody should be 'forced' to have the Covid jab, but it offers a substantial degree of protection to the individual and those they come into contact with.

Therefore, if you have the jab, you can expect to have a great deal more freedom to work and socialise as you choose. Fair.

Norman Tebbit talks a lot of sense in his latest Telegraph column. A reality check:

1. Covid cases & hospitalisations are heading in the WRONG direction.

2. Nobody is forcing you to have the vaccine, but you can expect a great deal more freedom to work and socialise if you do. https://t.co/W3N3KN9XCc

Despite the disappointing result, today's afternoon session was a wonderful advert for Test cricket. The horror of The Hundred is behind us (for now) and we can focus on the proper form of the game. It's a shame Test #cricket is so weak outside England, NZ, Australia & India now.

Credit to India's bowlers, who were deadly this afternoon, but England's batting lineup is very fragile, despite what we saw in the last Test. That middle order collapse 40 minutes after lunch today showed it for what it is. #cricket
@JeremyJacobs Morally and ethically, should Israel, or any other team, be going?

I don't buy into socialist ideology myself, but I DO share Shankly's belief in the importance of working together collectively for a greater good. No man is an island. We all rely on others

@TalkingSnooker @philhaigh_ Monday is big for soaps, though as you say, none are anything like as popular as they used to be (the BBC needs to persevere with EastEnders because they recently spent a fortune on a new set at Elstree). Love Island may also have been a factor re who has the remote control.

India's decision to leave Ravichandran Ashwin out yet again is baffling. He's the second best spin bowler in the world and is also a capable batsman. He also has a good track record of getting England batsmen out in India. There's more to this than we're being told. #cricket
@georgegalloway We can be thankful for the skill and quick-thinking of the paramedics. He is in the best possible hands now at the ICU. He and his family will remain in my thoughts and prayers.

This footage matters - Bill Shankly's quote about football being 'more important' than a matter of life and death is often misused. To understand it, you need to put it into context. Here is the video footage. He's clearly talking about how his commitment affected family life. https://t.co/kustIG8jQ7
@philhaigh_ Yeah I'm trying to remember what the competition for an audience would've been on other channels that night.

The format of the British Open wasn't to everybody's taste (I was critical of it), but we now know that live coverage dominated ITV4's viewing figures for the week, with more than 412,000 tuning in for the final. And public interest is ultimately what it's all about. #snooker https://t.co/39oFPPLHIE

Meghan Markle seemed to think that the Royal Family would adapt to 'Project Meghan', and unlike her sister-in-law Kate, she had no intention of adapting to a life of duty and service. https://t.co/xffkJokxus

ITV ought to bear in mind at 60,000 complaints today isn't the same as 60,000 complaints 20 years ago. A lot of these complainants aren't people with genuine grievances, but are people who have joined in a social media pile-on: https://t.co/xffkJokxus

Meghan has managed to fall out with: Her first husband, her father, her brother, her sister, Piers Morgan and the Queen. Her 'friends' are: Oprah Winfrey, Netflix and Spotify. she and Harry have chosen a sad, lonely, superficial life: https://t.co/xffkJokxus

The Ofcom verdict on ITV's silencing of Piers Morgan makes for damning reading. ITV's actions are described as "A chilling restriction on freedom of expression." I recorded this podcast with @greg_lw shortly after the Oprah interview: https://t.co/xffkJokxus

The Stand with Eamon Dunphy - "Young people be careful, long Covid can cause serious problems". Eamon talks to Tom√°s Ryan, Associate Professor at the School of Biochemistry & Immunology, Trinity College Dublin, and member of ISAG. Long Covid is no joke: https://t.co/ByKcfLySgl

Geronimo the alpaca RIP. I hope some of those who have been most vocal will now turn their concern to wider issues of animal welfare in this country, such as the conditions chickens are kept in, even those that are in theory 'free range'. There's lots more, too.
Daniel James is joining Leeds Utd for ¬£25 million.

Stefanos Tsitsipas's youth and fitness was telling in that deciding set. Andy Murray can be proud. Tournament organisers are going to great lengths to keep players and spectators safe. They ought to distance themselves from Tsitsipas's dangerous anti-vaccine rhetoric. #USOpen

Another aspect to this encounter is that Stefanos Tsitsipas is a wacko Covid vaccine conspiracy theorist who the Greek Prime Minister has spoken out against. Andy Murray has had Covid and has encouraged people to have the vaccine. In other words, good luck Andy Murray! #USOpen

If you're up late, put the US Open tennis on! Andy Murray is involved in a deciding set against world number three Stefanos Tsitsipas (runner-up at the French Open at the start of the summer). Murray is rolling back the years here! #USOpen

@theodore_bagwe I wasn't born until 1983, but I can name members of Harold Wilson and Jim Callaghan's Cabinets with ease - Tony Benn, Roy Jenkins, Denis Healey, Barbara Castle, Michael Foot. Nowadays, how many people can name the Shadow Chancellor and Shadow Foreign Secretary?

@LapovOnor Yeah, while testing figures aren't the be all and end all (if the kids are off school, they won't be being tested), it seems clear to me that by any standards, Covid figures are heading in the wrong direction at the moment.
@Matt_Lester @judd147t @Gary_Wilson11 Nice one! He's instantly recognisable!

I'm happy to give this a retweet - it'll be great for a collector. For those who weren't around at the time, Snooker Scene provided an accurate account of what was going on in the politics of the game during that era. Pot Black, to put it politely, did not. #snooker https://t.co/V3k9JmkHJ8

A quick glance at the BBC Genome website reveals that TV used to make a lot more effort on bank holidays (including August): Grandstand, Billy Smart's Circus, light entertainment from piers and from seaside theatres. There's not much to grab our attention on terrestrial TV today.

I wonder how the permanently-offended brigade who get worked up about GB News would cope with the late-night radio personalities we had up and down the country in the era before social media: Allan Beswick, Caesar the Geezer, James Stannage, Adrian Allen and others?

People voted for Brexit for a whole variety of reasons, and Mr Littlewood's experience is just one example.

For some, it was concerns about uncontrolled mass immigration. For others, it was loss of sovereignty. For others, it was the lack of democratic accountability in the EU. https://t.co/bEE0Rv637M

The County Championship is back, after a gap of a month-and-a-half, as a sort of late-summer afterthought. 

It's completely bonkers that during the height of summer, when the weather was good and when children were off school, that there was no long-form county cricket played.

For all the complete cock-ups the Conservatives have made recently, Labour are making little to no progress in the polls. The official opposition does not look like a government in waiting.Despite everything, if there was an election any time soon, the Conservatives would win big https://t.co/KrymAZlRzr
Yes. It's still the game's biggest challenge and it's what defines careers. https://t.co/epwgdTQc09

I'm either very unlucky in that I happen to know a lot of people with Covid-like symptoms at the moment (all of whom are doing the right thing in terms of isolating), or there's been a significant increase in recent weeks.

The jab helps speedy recovery, but isn't a miracle cure

@j_slatman The difference being that young people used to SAY stupid stuff, and it was quickly forgotten. Now they POST stupid stuff on social media and it can come back to damage them many years later when they're very different people.

@CiaranGibbons1 üòÇüòÇüòÇYeah, you're quite right. I'll never make it in modern television coming up with crazy stuff like this!

I'll send them my pitch for a new programme called 'Make Me A Celebrity Sandwich' instead. That's the sort of thing they go for these days!

@HorneyMedia Yes, that's very true. When Parky was at his peak in the 1970s (a far better programme than the 1990s/2000s revival), his guests were all people who had achieved something in life: Film stars, singers, comedians, poets and writers. 

Nowadays we have reality TV and 'influencers'.
@j_slatman Yes, you're right, but there's an element on the far left who take great delight in trawling through ancient tweets looking for the 'gotcha' moment that'll bring someone down.
@TheGreenBaize Yes, I actually think we live in a golden era for podcasts. There's a huge amount of material out there, and not enough hours in a day to listen to it.
@NeasdenParade Yeah, he was taken from us far too soon.

@PaulChantler I'm a bit too young to remember that era, and I didn't live in London anyway, but I fondly remember the years from 1995 when Gary was a regular on Talk Radio, which continued into the early days of talkSPORT. Oh and I enjoyed his Mirror column.
@Matthew_70s80s People playing to their echo chambers on Twitter? Surely not!

@NeasdenParade Yeah, Gary had a lot of media experience under his belt by the time Talk Radio started. I was too young to be working in the industry at the time, but that was a very exciting era. David Starkey was also good on Sunday mornings, then he moved to Sunday evenings for a short time.

@NeasdenParade Oh wow! I have great memories of listening to Gary Jacobs. In the early days of Talk Radio, he appeared on Caesar's late-night show once a week, and also had his own weekend show. He came and went a few times, but he had a good run on Sunday nights in the station's latter years.
@Matthew_70s80s Oh I'm well aware that a lot of fashionable comedians and TV personalities with very 'woke' and left-wing views are prone to thoroughly unpleasant behaviour on social media.
I haven't listened to this chap yet, but you've just brought back memories of the late Gary Jacobs on the radio! https://t.co/pf5fz01odo

@Matthew_70s80s We can't compare a fully-grown adult with the person they were when they were 16. But it's also true to say that people can change at any stage of their lives. Are your views on every subject exactly the same now as they were ten years ago? It's the present that really matters.
@MichaelRogerz "Never" is a long time, but with the way modern TV has gone, it's a genre that's sadly lacking nowadays.

@Sales_Rainmaker @jonnygould Arteta has had a lot of bad luck with injuries in the early weeks of the season, but I am wary of 'sentimental' managerial appointments, namely those who get the job because of their track records as players at the club long before, rather than their proven CV as a manager.
@Cartref35 It's hard to imagine the modern-day BBC commissioning a classy format like Parkinson or Wogan, and then allowing the guests to chat freely, that's for sure.
@MichaelRogerz It's an extraordinary archive. Frank Sinatra was 'the one that got away', but pretty much everyone else made it on there.
@CiaranGibbons1 I got my info on the army numbers from here. Do you think it's wrong? Or are they counting the numbers of active soldiers the wrong way?: https://t.co/DvL0Nf1o6g
@glennerboy This'll help refresh your memory: https://t.co/vFwGHiMx7n

I'm not saying comedy chat shows don't have their place on TV. They do. But modern TV badly lacks somebody like Michael Parkinson, Eamonn Andrews or Terry Wogan, who made the guests on their chat show the centre of attention, giving viewers the chance to learn a lot about them.
@glennerboy Sadly it had tragic consequences: https://t.co/77CJze5sAR

Following tonight's Parkinson at 50 programme, TV bosses might be interested in an idea for a chat show with a simple format: The host isn't the centre of attention, instead, he or she asks questions, listens to the answers, and then asks another question, like Parky & Wogan did.
@glennerboy I saw it many years later when the cat was long since out of the bag about it being a hoax. Lots of people were taken in by it!

I wrote this blog article after Michael Parkinson's appearance on Piers Morgan's Life Stories in 2019. It focuses on aspects of his career that aren't often talked about nowadays, such as his unsuccessful time with Tv-am, and his spell as an LBC presenter: https://t.co/YCzJyFvL4k
@glennerboy You may enjoy this article I wrote two years ago: https://t.co/YCzJyFvL4k

Michael Parkinson has become noticeably more frail in the last couple of years, but I still enjoyed tonight's documentary to mark 50 years of his chat show. As time passes, the show's archive is becoming a useful resource for learning about pioneering figures of stage and screen.

Further to my comments about Ollie Robinson, young people need to be aware that they're leaving behind a 'digital footprint'. I'm not a fan of 'Twitter archaeology', but we're in danger of becoming a society that condemns people for comments they made on social media years ago.

Ollie Robinson was absolutely superb this morning. Good on him for the way he's reacted to the events of the last few months - he's let his cricket do the talking. Do we REALLY want to live in a society that condemns people for foolish things they said when they were young?

@theodore_bagwe @lee_m987 @Cartref35 @Conservatives At its peak, the WDA attracted 20% of inward investment into the UK to Wales. Today, that figure stands at a miserable 2%.

@theodore_bagwe @lee_m987 @Cartref35 @Conservatives One of the big problems with the NHS (especially in England) is of people leaving the pay of the NHS and then being rehired via outside firms to do what is essentially the same job on an inflated wage. 

Sir Gerry Robinson had the right ideas on what needs to be done with it.
@theodore_bagwe @Cartref35 @lee_m987 @Conservatives The housing of refugees is a tiny cost compared to all the other stuff I listed in my earlier message.

@theodore_bagwe @lee_m987 @Cartref35 @Conservatives It's a mixture of high levels of welfare dependency, a bloated public sector, poor procurement in the public sector, and a need to service national debt (which has trebled since 2006).

@theodore_bagwe @lee_m987 @Cartref35 @Conservatives The Conservatives like to portray themselves as the party of the military, but over the last 11 years, they've made cuts that would've received far greater scrutiny if Labour had done the same thing.

There's not much difference at all between Blair and Cameron in policy terms.

There were 300,000 troops in the British Army in 1990. Today, there are 145,000.

The Royal Navy had 51 destroyers and frigates in 1990. By 2017 it had just 19.

Cutting spending to the army and navy has been seen as an 'easy option' for successive governments for far too long. https://t.co/0OK2ovowbB
@glennerboy I think it many well now happen a lot sooner than even the vested interests were planning.

@CiaranGibbons1 The UK adversarial, parliamentary system is breaking down because it only works effectively when there's an opposition that looks like a government in waiting. 

How many people even know the names of the Shadow Chancellor, Shadow Foreign Secretary, Shadow Home Secretary etc?

@theodore_bagwe @kimberleypipet Perhaps more importantly, there were a number of powerful vested interest groups that wanted to make him President, when there must surely have been many better-suited people.

For crying out loud! What is WRONG with people! 

I know this is an extreme example, but it's wise not to trust governments in general with too much of your data. Iris scans, fingerprints etc can fall into the wrong hands. 

A cynical, sceptical approach to authority is healthy. https://t.co/KXXyodizfk
@kimberleypipet Yes, with the state he's in, he should really be relaxing and spending time with his family. For him, personally, this is embarrassing. And for the world, it is very dangerous indeed.
@James_Clancy14 @theodore_bagwe We live in a dangerous and unstable world badly in need of leadership. And we're not getting it. I don't wish to play personality politics. There's too much at stake.
@theradgeygadgey 24 X 7 = 168. Maybe you're right!
My Google Home just told me Joe Biden is 24 years old... #Biden

@theodore_bagwe He's an elderly man whose cognitive functions have declined massively since his oratory peak in the 1980s and 90s. He was still good enough in that sense during his years as Vice President, but he's gone downhill a LOT since then. I'd actually say he's declined in the last year.
@glennerboy The truth is I don't listen to the station much nowadays aside from sports commentary. I have very fond memories of the 1990s and early 2000s line-up.

Joe Biden used to be a fairly convincing public speaker. He was a steady if unremarkable Senator. I wouldn't have agreed with much of his ideology, but I'd feel a lot happier with this 1988 version of Joe Biden in charge than what we have now: https://t.co/4MKdhXuLaO

@glennerboy It's not quite the force it once was when Alan Green, Mike Ingham and Ron Jones (lovely bloke) were in their pomp, plus phone-ins with Danny Baker and Richard Littlejohn, but it still has its strengths.
Surely it can't be long now before Kamala Harris is President? #Afghanistan

I have a great deal of personal sympathy on a human level for anyone suffering from dementia, but when the world needs leadership and clear thinking, we're not getting it. I had a strong dislike of Trump, but I warned people in January not to celebrate Biden's Presidency. https://t.co/bW2W8Smm0c

@glennerboy Thankfully he's recovered from health problems in recent times. I'm sure he'll adapt to the different demands of TV commentary. I look forward to hearing lots more of him in the months and years ahead.

There's so much I really love about the USA - the 'get up and go' attitude to life, the business success stories, the music, the movies, Broadway shows, the sport. They do it all brilliantly. 

But when it comes to their political leaders, voters have had lousy choices for years

What the world needs now is LEADERSHIP. Joe Biden's cognitive functions have declined massively in recent years. Boris Johnson neither a clear thinker nor a strategist. Macron and Trudeau are essentially overgrown, petulant children. Where will leadership come from? #Afghanistan

@BuddyGB I was going to refer to more contemporary examples, such as if fathers wanting reasonable access to their children after separating from the child's mother had blocked the roads up in the same way, or if a pro-Brexit protest was organised using the same tactics.

@iantobogg @fouldsy147 It's been a busy day with work so it'll be midnight highlights on BBC Two for me, but it looks as though it's been a terrific day with Root leading the way and the others more than pulling their weight for a change.

Ted Dexter RIP. His achievements will be well-documented elsewhere. I'm a bit young to remember his years on commentary, but I do remember him as Chairman of Selectors.

Well before my time, in 1964, he was Conservative candidate for Cardiff South East, and lost to Jim Callaghan. https://t.co/mpuV6uDH3e

@fouldsy147 Yeah, today has been terrific. Real quality with the ball and the opening batsmen have made a good start. But tomorrow we'll see whether England's batting line-up has turned a corner or whether the fragility and dependence on Root is still there.Test cricket is intriguing as ever
@flyinglawyer73 @Sales_Rainmaker I published this the other day, which you both might well have already read (I think Stephanie has). This clarifies things somewhat: https://t.co/R3Fa90cgyb

Jimmy Anderson, Craig Overton, Sam Curran and Ollie Robinson were superb today. England have made a good start with the bat, but there's still that fragility there. Once one of these openers is out, the over-reliance on Joe Root could become a factor again. #cricket

They'd be much more scathing if others caused this level of disruption.

Once this initial period of chaos in Afghanistan has calmed, we ought to look again at our alliances.

If I didn't pay my insurance premium, I wouldn't expect to be able to claim on it.

If NATO members don't spend the required 2% of GDP on defence, should they be in the club?
@Gerald_Ashley @Sales_Rainmaker @DailyCaller @roodio Presidents age at around double speed. If you've been in office eight years, you'll leave looking 16 years older.
Good luck to all #TeamGB competitors at the #Paralympics . These are athletes who despise self-pity, rise above pain and adversity and show us all what it can mean to be human, if we try.

Advice for those running TV news channels = When interviewing a guest at home, if their internet connection isn't great, better to use a standard phone line than rely on Skype/Zoom connections that may well cut out

Advice for regular contributors = invest in a decent microphone!

Sad to hear that Adrian Metcalfe has died at the age of 79. He was a member of Britain‚Äôs 4x400 metres relay team that won silver at the 1964 Olympic Games in Tokyo. He did a huge amount with his life - he was the first head of sport at Channel 4 & helped the London 2012 bid. RIP.

@glennerboy I think communications need to be improved. The reality is that a lot of us know someone who has died from or with Covid, and there are a million people in Britain right now living with the effects of long Covid. A mix of calm pragmatism and stoicism is what's needed.

It seems clear to me that we would benefit from being a lot less touchy - feely as a society, even when restrictions are lifted. Hugging and kissing people beyond our immediate families and very close friends isn't a good idea. Tightly-packed trains etc should also be avoided.

@glennerboy The vaccine offers a great deal of protection against the Delta strain, but it does spread more easily than future strains.

If a future strain isn't as well-protected by the vaccine, and/or spreads easily, it would be foolish to rule out further lockdowns in the long term.

* None of us knows what length of time having two doses of the vaccine buys us in terms of immunity. 

* The vaccine appears to be effective against the newer emerging strains, but nobody can be sure how effective it'll be against future strains.

These are the key issues for me.

There are 2 things we can take from the press conference:

1. Covid is here to stay, it's a case of learning to live with it. 

2. It's entirely possible we'll need annual vaccines for the foreseeable future, possibly for the rest of our lives.

@chrisstlmo Man Utd were relegated in the 1970s. Leeds Utd were relegated more than once. Leicester City have won the Premier League, as have Blackburn Rovers. Nottingham Forest went from second tier to European champions within the space of a few seasons.

One of football's main strengths in England and well beyond is the dream that your club could one day climb the ladder and reach the top flight, win it, and play in European competitions. The Super League breakaway plan destroys that dream. It's arrogance. https://t.co/zkefb3Dmu1

@chrisstlmo "None of the super league teams would ever be relegated" 

'Never' is a long, long time. Giants have fallen before. At some point, they will do again.

More than two decades ago, UEFA staved off plans for a European Super League by expanding the Champions League to include far more than just the league champions from respective countries. Now they're expanding the Champions League further to try and appease big clubs.

There is a real arrogance about these plans for a European Super League. Without a promotion and relegation structure, they're of the belief that the best teams now will be the best teams in five, ten or 20 years' time. That's not how football works: https://t.co/zkefb3Dmu1

There's a mentality among many leftists that all landlords are villains and all tenants are saints. The truth is there are good and bad in both. 

Yes, tenants deserve protection from bad landlords and the pandemic.

But landlords also deserve protection from bad tenants.

Politicians and trade unions who have spoken out about the landlord and tenant situation today have very little understanding of the reality. I found the same thing in my dealings with Vaughan Gething in Wales when he was housing minister here.

A tenancy agreement is like any other legally-binding agreement. If you break it, there are consequences. It is already very hard for landlords to retrieve money from tenants who default. There is already help in place for tenants who are in difficulty due to the pandemic.

Most landlords are ordinary people who have either become landlords via inheritance, or have a small number of properties which they use primarily to fund their pensions. They are not excessively wealthy people on the whole. They deserve protection from bad tenants.

"Handing over public money to wealthy landlords who can afford to absorb the cost of missed rent payments will only make the problems in our rigged housing system worse," said Amina Gichinga from London Renters Union.

There's a lot of snobbery and bigotry in that statement.

@ToshFan44 @theodore_bagwe The process was certainly underway pre-Covid, but a process that might have taken another ten years to play out has now taken place in a matter of months, and there is no going back.

@theodore_bagwe A friend of mine who normally used to work in a Cardiff city centre office used to have to get up early, take an overcrowded train to work, same going home. Now he works from home, logs on in the morning, logs off late afternoon, much less stress, more time with wife & children.

There's no 'one size fits all' when it comes to #darts. Throws are different, darts are different, flights are different. Some players need to practice for hours every day. For Jonny Clayton, a solid 90 minutes after finishing the day job works for him. It's each to their own.

Jonny Clayton would be well-advised to stick to his routine of practising 90 minutes per day, for the simple reason that it very clearly works! He may have to cut back his hours as a plasterer because of Premier League commitments, but not playing #darts all day works for him.

Yet again ITV have demonstrated this weekend that their #darts coverage is absolutely top notch. Jacqui Oatley is a decent presenter, while pundits Chris Mason and Alan Warriner-Little speak their minds. There's enough distance between them and the players to speak objectively.

@BuddyGB That process has been taking place for well over two decades now. Ofcom stood back and did nothing, but also the commercial reality in radio has changed. Google and Facebook have hoovered up most advertising revenue. Radio audiences are much more fragmented as well.
@TheVietGwent The likes of Ronald Reagan managed to reach across the divide to expand his appeal and keep a sense of national unity and purpose. The current leaders do the exact opposite.

One of the grim lessons of the first two decades of the 21st century is that economic prosperity does not necessarily come hand in hand with democracy and personal liberty. In the 20th century, the two were widely-regarded as entwined. That's no longer the case.

I can remember every President from George HW Bush onwards. I grew up in an era when the USA was a shining beacon of hope for oppressed people everywhere in terms of democracy, the rule of law and freedom. Tonight, that feels like a very long time ago. It's very sad to see.

Outside the top flight, football highlights work best on a regional level. TV coverage has gone backwards in the last 20 years in that sense. We had regular Sunday afternoon highlights on regional ITV, plus midweek programmes which also covered the League Cup.

We've had two entertaining Carabao Cup semi-finals over the last two nights, but it's a great shame the competition doesn't have a higher profile. Both semis were live on Sky, with highlights on Quest. There aren't even highlights on a high-profile free-to-air channel.

A decade ago, nobody would've believed you if you said we'd witness scenes like this in Washington tonight. I have no time for either Donald Trump or Joe Biden, but the USA is a country ill at ease with itself and it'll be a difficult thing to repair.

How do we fight back against Google, Amazon and Facebook manipulating us?

* Use alternative search engines to Google, such as DuckDuckGo.

Small actions by each of us as individuals.

A true #Brexit means:

* National sovereignty
* The supremacy of UK courts
* The ability to control immigration
* The ability to form trade deals with the wider world
* An independent foreign policy

If the deal compromises any of these, it's a bad deal. Let's examine the detail

At this moment in time, I don't know what's in any potential #Brexit deal, and neither do you.

But certain people have already decided it's a sell-out, while some in the EU will claim the UK has given huge amounts of ground.

Let's all calm down and examine the detail.
